system_warning: Historical units varied by region and era. Use for interpretive reference, not precision formulation. Always verify against the specific text and historical context.

units.historical_note: The modern market jin (shijin) was standardized to exactly 500g in 1959. Historical jin values varied significantly by dynasty and region.
Classical Han dynasty liang ≈ 15.6g, not modern 50g. Do not convert classical text doses using modern values without scholarly context.
Modern qian = 1/10 liang = 5g. This is the most common unit for individual herb doses in modern TCM prescriptions.
Modern fen = 1/10 qian = 0.5g. Used for potent substances requiring small doses.

The liang of Zhang Zhongjing's Shang Han Lun era. Scholarly estimates range from 13.8g to 15.6g. This value (15.6g) follows the standard archaeological interpretation. Doses in the Shang Han Lun appear large by modern standards but are well-documented in the historical record.
Song dynasty standardization increased the liang to approximately 40g. Many formularies from this period use this weight.
The liang remained relatively stable through Ming and Qing dynasties at approximately 37.3g. This is the basis for many materia medica texts still in circulation.
The tola is standardized in India at 11.6638g (= 3/8 troy ounce). It remains in common use for gold trading and traditional medicine. Also spelled 'tolah'.
1/12 tola ≈ 0.97g. Often rounded to 1g in modern practice. The masha is used for dosing powdered herbs (churnas) in Ayurvedic formulations.
1/8 masha ≈ 0.12g. Based on the weight of a gunja seed (Abrus precatorius). Used for very potent substances. Historical values range 0.11-0.13g.
4 tola = 1 pala ≈ 46.64g. A common unit for larger quantities in Ayurvedic preparation.
The mithqal varies by region: 4.25-5.0g. The value 4.68g is based on the standard Islamic mithqal of 72 grains of barley. Used in Unani Tibb (Graeco-Arabic medicine) pharmacopeias.
The dirham (from Greek drachma) varies historically from 2.8-3.2g. The value 3.12g follows the standard pharmaceutical dirham. Used widely in Unani formulation texts.
